abstract.p: Ester S Buchholz letter on Aug 4 article on baby's need for attachment to its mother says babies also gain from solitude; drawing

block.p: Now that Dr. Michael Lewis, a professor of pediatrics, leads the way to a re-evaluation of a baby's need for attachment to its mother (Science Times, Aug. 4), room is left for a balanced view of child-rearing practices. For example, children enter the world with inborn skills to soothe themselves and continue to learn that they can thrive when alone. Children need concerned and attentive parents. But they also gain from solitude.
ESTER S. BUCHHOLZ New York, Aug. 4, 1998
